study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the use of plant-based products, such as miswak and herbal toothpaste, in dental practice and their potential benefits as adjunctive therapy.
results_summary: The study highlights the historical and ongoing use of plant-derived products in dentistry, noting their anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and antifungal properties, which can enhance dental treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of phytodentistry applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GutsyGum(tm) was more effective than placebo gum in alleviating symptoms of gastro-esophageal reflux (GER) after a refluxogenic meal.
results_summary: GutsyGum(tm) significantly reduced heartburn and acid reflux scores compared to placebo, with pain also showing a trend toward improvement. Secondary outcomes like nausea and belching were lower but not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 24 participants with a history of GER.
study_duration: Single administration with follow-up to four hours postmeal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical utility of computerized measurement devices in managing temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) and assess the effectiveness of TMJ injection therapy in improving mouth opening and chewing function.
results_summary: The study found that TMJ injection therapy significantly improved maximum mouth opening (MMO) in 11 prior studies, but the 2013 study showed only a minor, insignificant improvement. The authors concluded that the measurement device was clinically useless, contrasting with their earlier findings.
population_specificity: Subjects with temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) and limited mouth opening.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kefir drink could be an effective alternative to fluoride rinse in reducing mutans streptococci (MS) levels in saliva.
results_summary: The study found that Kefir drink significantly reduced MS counts in saliva, with an effect comparable to 0.05% sodium fluoride rinse. No significant difference was observed in baseline pH values between the groups.
population_specificity: 22 healthy volunteers aged 22-32 years with good oral hygiene, no active caries, and no recent antibiotic or fluoride therapy.
effective_dosage: 100 ml of Kefir drink per day.
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention phase, with a washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a sugar-free chewing gum containing calcium hydroxyapatite in reducing dentin hypersensitivity compared to a placebo gum.
results_summary: The test gum group showed statistically significant reductions in dentin hypersensitivity across all clinical test indexes (tactile, air blast, cold water) after one and two weeks, outperforming the placebo group. The reductions were greater at two weeks, with the test gum demonstrating superior efficacy (p < 0.01 to p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 107 subjects (100 completed) with dentin hypersensitivity, randomly allocated into test and control groups.
effective_dosage: Two pieces of chewing gum, three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of sugar-free chewing gum as part of a multidisciplinary approach to managing xerostomia and improving patients' quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that sugar-free chewing gum can help relieve dry-mouth symptoms and improve quality of life when used as part of a comprehensive management strategy for xerostomia, alongside other palliative and preventive measures.
population_specificity: Patients with xerostomia (dry mouth), often associated with medication use, chronic disease, or medical treatments like radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of CPP-ACP on dental health, including its ability to reduce demineralization, promote remineralization, and inhibit cariogenic activity.
results_summary: CPP-ACP was found to stabilize calcium phosphate in dental plaque, buffer free calcium and phosphate ions, and promote enamel remineralization. It effectively treated white spot lesions, hypomineralised enamel, mild fluorosis, tooth sensitivity, and erosion, while also preventing plaque accumulation around orthodontic appliances.
population_specificity: General dental health applications, including individuals with orthodontic appliances and primary teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of chewing gum as a potential treatment strategy for alleviating symptoms of postoperative ileus (POI).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that chewing gum may modulate brain peptides and vagal signaling pathways to shorten the duration of POI, but specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing abdominal surgery (postoperative ileus context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum could reduce postoperative ileus (POI) and improve recovery outcomes in adults after abdominal surgery.
results_summary: Patients who chewed gum postoperatively experienced reduced POI, passed flatus and defecated sooner, had shorter hospital stays, and reported higher satisfaction compared to non-gum-chewing controls. The results were consistent across multiple studies, though limitations included small sample sizes and variability in gum-chewing protocols.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing abdominal surgery (excluding cesarean section).
effective_dosage: Not specified (variable timing and frequency among studies).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of intervention varied by study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of xylitol usage in ENT practice, particularly for preventing otitis media, rhinosinusitis, and dental caries.
results_summary: Xylitol enhances innate immunity and has anti-adhesive effects on microorganisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus mutans, inhibiting their growth. It shows promise for preventing ENT-related infections but requires further experimental and clinical studies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general ENT practice context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of silicone versus alginate impression materials for creating dentures, focusing on patient preference and functional outcomes like chewing efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that 67.9% of patients preferred dentures made from silicone impressions over alginate, with a statistically significant 50% difference in preference rates. Silicone-based dentures were rated higher for comfort, stability, and chewing efficiency.
population_specificity: 85 patients recruited at Leeds Dental Institute, UK, meeting published eligibility criteria.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study compared impression materials, not dosages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetics of raltegravir (RAL) when taken by chewing versus swallowing, focusing on drug absorption and variability.
results_summary: Chewing RAL tablets resulted in significantly higher drug exposure and reduced pharmacokinetic variability compared to swallowing, with no difference in minimum concentrations. The study suggests chewing 800 mg once daily may improve absorption and compliance over swallowing 400 mg twice daily.
population_specificity: 12 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 400 mg every 12 hours (swallowed) vs. 800 mg once daily (chewed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential risks of tooth erosion and demineralization caused by acidic or EDTA-containing oral hygiene products, chewable tablets, and medications.
results_summary: The study found that low-pH oral hygiene products and certain chewable medications can soften dental hard tissues and cause erosion, particularly in patients with xerostomia. While fluoride can offer some protection, prolonged use of acidic products increases erosion risk.
population_specificity: Patients using oral hygiene products, chewable tablets, or medications, particularly those with xerostomia.
interactions: Mentioned interactions with tranquilizers, antihistamines, antiemetics, antiparkinsonian medications, and salivary gland dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess jaw muscle function in edentulous patients with full fixed prostheses on a limited number of implants (≤6) compared to dentate subjects and other prosthetic options.
results_summary: The study found that patients with full fixed prostheses on limited implants showed satisfactory neuromuscular equilibrium in static activities but had some impairment during chewing compared to dentate controls.
population_specificity: Edentulous patients restored with full fixed prostheses on ≤6 implants, compared to dentate subjects and those with dentures, implant-supported overdentures, or prostheses on >6 implants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the historical use, chemical composition, and oral health effects of miswak (Salvadora persica) compared to modern oral hygiene tools.
results_summary: The study found that miswak has antimicrobial, anticariogenic, antiplaque, and antigingivitis effects, with some evidence suggesting it may be more beneficial than toothbrushes and toothpaste in certain contexts. It also highlighted its probiotic role and cell viability, supporting its use as a traditional oral hygiene tool.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on culturally diverse groups using miswak.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of two denture adhesives (Ultra Corega cream and powder) on the masticatory performance of conventional complete denture wearers.
results_summary: Both denture adhesives significantly improved masticatory performance compared to no adhesive, with no significant difference between the cream and powder forms.
population_specificity: Forty edentulous individuals wearing new maxillary and mandibular complete dentures.
study_duration: 15 days per adhesive with a 15-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum increases the risk of aspiration during sedation.
results_summary: The study found that patients who chewed gum within the past 6 hours may theoretically be at increased risk of aspiration during procedural sedation, though conclusive evidence was limited. The clinical bottom line suggests considering this risk when deciding on sedation use.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing procedural sedation.

study_goal: To compare the plaque removal efficacy of an oscillating-rotating power brush versus a newly-introduced sonic power brush.
results_summary: Both brushes significantly reduced plaque over 4 weeks, but the oscillating-rotating brush was statistically significantly more effective (P < 0.001), with plaque reduction scores more than five times greater for whole mouth and approximal areas compared to the sonic brush.
population_specificity: Subjects with pre-existing plaque scores of at least 1.75 on the TMQHPI.
effective_dosage: Brushed twice daily with assigned brush and standard fluoride dentifrice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify common causes of unintentional weight loss in older adults and suggest diagnostic and treatment approaches, including dietary modifications for chewing or swallowing disabilities.
results_summary: The study found that dietary modifications accounting for chewing or swallowing disabilities may help address unintentional weight loss, but no specific efficacy or safety data on chewing itself were provided.
population_specificity: Persons older than 65 years experiencing unintentional weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction, including chewing, between immediate and conventional loading protocols for fixed full-arch implant-supported maxillary rehabilitation.
results_summary: In the immediate loading group, satisfaction with chewing increased significantly by 3 months, while the conventional loading group saw a significant decrease in chewing satisfaction at 3 months. After 12 months, there were no differences in chewing satisfaction between the groups.
population_specificity: Partially edentulous patients requiring extraction of remaining maxillary dentition and rehabilitation with fixed full-arch prostheses (n=29).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetic profiles and assess bioequivalence of a new orally soluble film formulation of sildenafil (taken without water or chewing) with a conventional film-coated tablet.
results_summary: The orally soluble film formulation showed no significant pharmacokinetic differences compared to the conventional tablet, with bioequivalence demonstrated for Cmax, AUClast, and AUCinf. The OSF formulation offers a convenient alternative without requiring water or chewing.
population_specificity: 48 healthy male subjects
study_duration: Single-dose administration with blood sampling over 24 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three different prosthetic interventions (RPDs, IRPDs, and IFPDs) in restoring masticatory function in partially edentulous patients.
results_summary: Both IRPDs and IFPDs improved masticatory ability and reduced chewing cycle times compared to RPDs, with no significant difference between the two implant-supported prostheses.
population_specificity: 12 partially edentulous subjects (mean age 62.6 ± 7.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on oral manifestations and orofacial function in ectodermal dysplasias (EDs), focusing on dental manifestations crucial for differential diagnosis.
results_summary: The study found that disturbances in tooth development, abnormalities in tooth number/size/shape, reduced salivary secretion, and compromised orofacial function (including chewing) are common in EDs. There is a clinical overlap in oral signs between isolated oligodontia and common EDs, necessitating refined diagnostics.
population_specificity: Individuals with ectodermal dysplasias (EDs), particularly those with hypodontia, oligodontia, or genetically verified diagnoses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare maximum occlusal bite force (MBF) between implant-supported fixed prostheses and natural dentition in the same subjects and assess the influence of gender, age, and BMI on MBF.
results_summary: The study found that MBF was slightly higher (3%) on the dentate side compared to the implant-supported prosthesis side, with males, taller individuals, and those with higher weights exhibiting greater MBF. BMI did not significantly affect MBF values.
population_specificity: 40 patients (20 males, 20 females; mean age 42.7 ± 9.6 years) with an implant-supported fixed prosthesis on one side and natural dentition on the other.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate posterior alveolar ridge resorption (PARR) in patients with two implant-supported mandibular overdentures over ten years.
results_summary: The study found an average area-related PARR rate of 1.02% per year, with individual variations ranging from 0.15% to 2.63% per year. The estimated average ten-year vertical bone loss in the chewing center was 1.5 mm, aligning with previously reported ranges for different implant restorations.
population_specificity: 23 patients with two implant-supported mandibular overdentures.
study_duration: Mean observation period of 9.4 years (±2.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of chewing gum containing allyl isothiocyanate and zinc salts on reducing volatile sulfur compounds responsible for oral malodor.
results_summary: The study found that chewing gum with 0.1% zinc lactate and 0.01% allyl isothiocyanate significantly reduced volatile sulfur compounds by 89% immediately after chewing, with reductions of 55.5%, 48%, and 24% at 1, 2, and 3 hours post-chewing, respectively.
population_specificity: 15 healthy volunteers aged 20-50.
effective_dosage: 0.1% zinc lactate and 0.01% allyl isothiocyanate in chewing gum.
study_duration: 12 minutes of chewing, with follow-up measurements up to 180 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of short-term xylitol gum chewing on the salivary microbiota and mutans streptococci (MS) levels in children.
results_summary: Xylitol gum chewing reduced viable counts of MS in saliva but did not alter the overall salivary microbiota composition. Similar MS reductions were observed in the sorbitol control group.
population_specificity: Healthy children
effective_dosage: Approximately 6 g/day of xylitol or sorbitol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether chewing gum, olive oil, or both could effectively reduce postoperative ileus compared to water or control treatments in various abdominal surgeries.
results_summary: Chewing gum did not show a relevant reduction in postoperative ileus, while water demonstrated earlier passage of flatus and stool and shorter hospital stays in some surgical groups. Olive oil and chewing gum combined showed earlier stool passage in gastric surgery patients compared to controls.
population_specificity: 360 patients undergoing abdominal surgery (videolaparoscopic cholecystectomy, laparotomic colo-rectal surgery, laparotomic Hartmann procedure, laparotomic gastric surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effect of sugar-free chewing gum sweetened with xylitol or maltitol on gingivitis and plaque scores under brushing and non-brushing conditions.
results_summary: In non-brushing conditions, xylitol and maltitol gums significantly reduced gingivitis scores compared to gum base, but not compared to no gum. No effect was observed in brushing conditions.
population_specificity: 220 participants with experimental gingivitis in the lower jaw.
effective_dosage: Chewing gum used five times a day for 10 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the contemporary management of toothwear using resin composite restorations and assess its advantages and disadvantages.
results_summary: The study found that bonding resin composite restorations at an increased occlusal vertical dimension is minimally invasive and has high patient satisfaction, but it may cause short-term issues like lisping, pain from orthodontic tooth movement, and difficulty chewing on posterior teeth.
population_specificity: Patients with severe toothwear requiring restorative treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of gum chewing in enhancing bowel motility and reducing postoperative ileus in women after caesarean section.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of six RCTs showed that gum chewing significantly reduced time to first flatus, bowel sound, stool passage, and hospital stay compared to no gum chewing, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: Women who underwent caesarean section.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of direct composite splinting for managing cracked tooth syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study found that 131 out of 151 composite restorations were successful at 3 months, with transient chewing problems reported in 94 cases. Failures were due to pulp complications, composite failure, or intolerance to the high restoration.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with cracked tooth syndrome (CTS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of denture adhesive use on masticatory function in denture wearers with normal or resorbed ridges.
results_summary: Denture adhesive use improved masticatory performance and ability in both ridge types, with the greatest improvement seen in resorbed ridge subjects using DA cream. The denture-bearing ridge status alone did not affect masticatory function.
population_specificity: Thirty edentulous subjects wearing new well-fitting dentures, classified as having either normal or resorbed ridges.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if postoperative gum chewing reduces the duration of postoperative ileus symptoms after elective open or laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy compared to standard care or an attention-control intervention.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences among the three groups (standard care, attention-control patch, and gum chewing) for postoperative outcomes like first passage of flatus, bowel movement, return of hunger, or tolerance of solid food. Postoperative gum chewing was not more effective than standard care or the attention-control intervention in reducing ileus symptoms, length of stay, or complications.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for open or laparoscopic colon resection (47 subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (gum chewing frequency/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether symmetric or asymmetric dental occlusion blocks could significantly alter spine position during standing and walking.
results_summary: The study found that both symmetrical and asymmetrical occlusion blocks led to significant changes in spine position across all three regions (cervical, thoracic, lumbar) during standing and walking, with the lumbar spine showing the most pronounced differences between standing and walking. The results suggest a relationship between chewing and the movement system, though clinical significance remains unclear.
population_specificity: 23 healthy subjects (18 women, 5 men) without temporomandibular or body movement discomfort.
effective_dosage: 4 mm thick silicon panels placed systematically between left/right premolars or front teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to correlate chewing habits (frequency, duration) with clinical, functional, and histopathological severity of oral submucosal fibrosis (OSMF).
results_summary: Increased duration and frequency of chewing gutkha significantly worsened OSMF severity, with strong correlations between habits and disease staging but not histopathological grading.
population_specificity: 90 subjects (80 OSMF patients, 10 controls), predominantly males aged 21-30 years in India.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration of chewing habits noted, but not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review age-associated risk factors affecting oral function and oral disease to inform care pathways for older individuals.
results_summary: The study found that reduced chewing ability negatively impacts dietary quality, especially in individuals with xerostomia, and that age-related physical and biological changes exacerbate oral health challenges like caries and periodontal disease.
population_specificity: Older people, including those with fewer teeth or edentulism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the challenges and solutions related to chewing in geriatric patients, focusing on the impact of edentulism, denture adaptation, and the role of implant overdentures in improving oral health-related quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that implant overdentures significantly improve chewing efficiency and prevent peri-implant bone loss, reversing some functional, psychological, and psychosocial effects of tooth loss. However, few studies have investigated the problems and survival rates when patients lose autonomy.
population_specificity: Geriatric patients, particularly those with edentulism, cognitive impairment, and multiple co-morbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the behavior, treatment, and outcomes of gingivobuccal complex cancers linked to chewing smokeless tobacco and areca nut.
results_summary: The study found that gingivobuccal mucosal cancers often present as large lesions with early mandibular involvement and cervical node metastasis, requiring surgical resection and reconstruction. Prognostic factors include tumor depth, skin involvement, and nodal metastases.
population_specificity: Southeast Asian subcontinent, particularly individuals with habits of chewing smokeless tobacco and areca nut.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Orbit White chewing gum in preventing extrinsic tooth stains compared to brushing alone in stain-forming adults.
results_summary: The study found a 25% reduction in new stain formation using the Lobene Stain Index and a 36% reduction using the Modified Lobene Stain Index when the gum was chewed alongside brushing, compared to brushing alone. Both reductions were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults prone to tooth staining from smoking or drinking coffee or tea, starting with stain-free teeth.
effective_dosage: Chewed four times per day, 15 minutes per chew.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of gum chewing after surgery as part of a rapid rehabilitation program in colorectal surgery.
results_summary: The study identified gum chewing after surgery as one of the tactics insufficiently applied in current rehabilitation programs, suggesting it may aid recovery. Consensus was reached among experts, with strong agreement on its inclusion in recommendations.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess pain, masticatory performance, and swallowing threshold in patients undergoing orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances.
results_summary: Pain significantly increased 24 hours after orthodontic activation but returned to baseline after 30 days. Masticatory performance was temporarily reduced at 24 hours but recovered by 30 days, while swallowing threshold remained unaffected throughout.
population_specificity: Ten patients (mean age 17.25 ± 5.21 years) with complete permanent dentition undergoing orthodontic treatment.
study_duration: 30 days (evaluated at baseline, 24 hours, and 30 days post-activation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the long-term quality of life, including chewing function, among head and neck cancer survivors treated with IMRT.
results_summary: Five years post-IMRT, most patients reported improved quality of life, with 80% rating their functioning as "outstanding" or "very good." Chewing was one of the assessed domains, but specific results for chewing were not detailed beyond overall positive trends.
population_specificity: Long-term survivors (≥5 years) of locally advanced head and neck cancer treated with bilateral neck IMRT, clinically disease-free.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of sham feeding (gum chewing) in improving gastrointestinal recovery and reducing hospital stay after colorectal surgery, particularly in the context of modern rapid postoperative feeding protocols.
results_summary: Sham feeding reduced time to flatus by 31 minutes, time to first bowel movement by 30 minutes, and length of hospital stay by 0.5 days, with lower complication rates. However, no benefits were observed in trials using rapid postoperative feeding.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing colorectal resection surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between occlusal interferences (nonworking interferences) and bruxism.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant relationship between bruxism and nonworking interferences, but no significant relationship with centric relation or other eccentric movements. Assisted nonworking occlusal contacts were more prevalent than unassisted ones.
population_specificity: 60 subjects (30 bruxers and 30 nonbruxers, with 14 males and 46 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a new smoking cessation service package, including nicotine replacement chewing gum, against traditional methods in diabetic and/or hypertensive smokers at risk of CVD.
results_summary: The study evaluated a multicomponent intervention, including nicotine replacement chewing gum, but specific results regarding chewing gum's efficacy were not detailed in the abstract. The primary outcome was smoking cessation rates at 1-year follow-up.
population_specificity: 440 current smokers at CVD risk (diabetic and/or hypertensive) in Thailand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate methods to alleviate thirst and xerostomia in maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients, specifically testing the effects of chewing gum and straw use.
results_summary: Chewing gum significantly reduced thirst (DTI, VAS thirst score), xerostomia (XI, VAS xerostomia score), and inter-dialytic weight gain (IDWG). Straw use also reduced thirst and IDWG, though less consistently than chewing gum.
population_specificity: Maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients (42 observational, 11 crossover trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an update on the epidemiology of oral cancers in Asian countries between 2000 and 2012, focusing on risk factors such as betel-quid chewing, tobacco, and alcohol use.
results_summary: The study found high incidence rates of oral cancers in developing Asian nations, with betel-quid chewing, tobacco use, and alcohol consumption identified as major risk factors. The tongue, buccal mucosa, and gingiva were the most common sites for oral cancers, and 5-year survival rates remained low despite advancements in diagnosis and treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals in South and Southeast Asian countries, particularly India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Taiwan, and Sri Lanka.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing studies on oral lichen planus (OLP) in the Arab world, including potential links to cultural factors like Deram chewing, as well as infections such as H. pylori and HCV.
results_summary: The review identified a possible association between OLP and Deram chewing, H. pylori, and HCV infections, with HCV prevalence ranging from 14.7% to 26.3% in OLP patients. However, the lack of population-based studies limits the generalizability of these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with oral lichen planus (OLP) in the Arab world.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare quality of life outcomes, including chewing function, between young (≤40 years) and older patients with anterior tongue squamous cell carcinoma.
results_summary: Young patients reported better chewing function compared to older patients, with chewing being one of the best-scoring domains in their quality of life assessment.
population_specificity: Patients younger than 40 years with anterior tongue squamous cell carcinoma, compared to matched older patients (controls).
study_duration: Median follow-up duration was 3.7 years (range: 1-12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a prosthodontist's clinical experience affects the treatment satisfaction of complete denture wearers, particularly in terms of chewing ability and other functional aspects.
results_summary: The study found that general satisfaction and specific aspects like speaking, stability, and retention were significantly higher in the ED (experienced dentist) group compared to the ID (inexperienced dentist) group. While overall mastication index (MI) did not differ significantly, perceived chewing ability for the hardest-textured food was significantly better in the ED group.
population_specificity: 74 edentulous patients (32 in the ED group, 30 in the ID group).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on dentist experience, not dosage).
study_duration: April 2004 to July 2006 (approximately 2 years and 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing the number of chews before swallowing could reduce food intake and aid in body-weight management.
results_summary: Increasing the number of chews to 150% and 200% of baseline significantly reduced food intake by 9.5% and 14.8%, respectively, prolonged meal duration, and reduced eating rate, but did not affect subjective appetite at meal termination or postprandially.
population_specificity: 18- to 45-year-old normal-weight, overweight, and obese participants (n=45) recruited from the local community (Ames, IA).
effective_dosage: 100%, 150%, and 200% of baseline number of chews per portion of food.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of removable partial denture prostheses (RPDP) on masticatory parameters such as particle size reduction, chewing cycles, and chewing time.
results_summary: The study found that RPDP improved the ability to reduce bolus particle size (lower D50 values) and decreased the number of chewing cycles, chewing time, and chewing frequency, though it did not fully restore masticatory function to normative levels.
population_specificity: 19 RPDP wearers (10 Kennedy Class III and 9 Class I partially edentulous subjects) with a complete opposing dentate arch.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (chewing tests with and without RPDP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate denture satisfaction and functional outcomes in very old edentulous patients after converting mandibular complete dentures to implant overdentures (IODs).
results_summary: IODs improved denture stability, satisfaction, and oral health-related quality of life, with increased bite force and masseter muscle thickness, though chewing efficiency did not differ between groups. Nutritional markers showed no significant differences.
population_specificity: Very old edentulous patients (average age ~85 years) dependent on help for daily activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health-related quality of life (QoL) of patients with oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma treated with chemoradiotherapy versus conventional surgery with or without adjuvant treatment, focusing on domains like chewing, swallowing, saliva, and speech.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in health-related QoL between the two treatment groups, though the surgical group recorded higher scores in most QoL domains, including chewing, swallowing, saliva, and speech. Both treatments provided acceptable QoL outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity treated at the Royal Brisbane & Women's Hospital between 2000 and 2011, who were alive without disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the hepatotoxic effects of commonly used illicit substances, including khat chewing, alongside alcohol-related liver disease and paracetamol hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that illicit drug abuse, including khat chewing, can cause liver abnormalities ranging from asymptomatic liver function test derangements to fulminant hepatic failure, but specific findings on chewing are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of substance abuse-related hepatotoxicity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum could reduce small-bowel transit time and increase capsule endoscopy completion rates.
results_summary: Chewing gum had no significant effect on gastric transit time, small-bowel transit time, or completion rate of capsule endoscopy. The study concluded that chewing gum does not speed up capsule transit or increase completion rates in patients without risk factors for incomplete studies.
population_specificity: Consecutive patients aged 19 and older undergoing outpatient small-bowel capsule endoscopy, excluding those with specific medical conditions or recent medication use.
effective_dosage: Chewing gum for at least 20 minutes every 2 hours starting at the time of capsule ingestion.
study_duration: Duration of the capsule endoscopy procedure (not explicitly stated, but likely several hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality of care for feeding problems, including chewing and swallowing issues, in advanced dementia patients and assess predictors of weight loss and mortality.
results_summary: The study found that 80% of residents with advanced dementia had chewing and swallowing problems, and weight loss was a significant predictor of mortality. Treatments could sometimes stabilize weight, but weight loss often triggered discussions about care goals.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents with advanced dementia and feeding problems (N = 256).
study_duration: Data collected at enrollment and 3, 6, and 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of four treatment strategies (medical management, non-surgical rehabilitation, arthroscopic surgery, and arthroplasty) for TMJ disc displacement without reduction, focusing on outcomes including chewing impairment.
results_summary: All four treatment strategies showed significant improvement in IAOMS-recommended outcomes over time, with no differences between treatments. Patient-reported success correlated with improved chewing ability, pain-free mouth opening, and reduced pain intensity.
population_specificity: 106 patients with MRI-confirmed TMJ closed lock (disc displacement without reduction with limited mouth opening).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review case reports of oral adverse reactions caused by cinnamon-containing chewing gums and propose a diagnostic algorithm for cinnamon contact stomatitis (CCS).
results_summary: The study found that cinnamon-flavored chewing gums can cause contact stomatitis (CCS), which is often misdiagnosed due to overlapping symptoms with other oral disorders. A multidisciplinary diagnostic approach was suggested to improve accuracy.
population_specificity: Individuals experiencing oral adverse reactions to cinnamon-containing chewing gums (case reports and case series).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collate available evidence on the characteristics of proliferative verrucous leucoplakia (PVL), including its demographics, aetiology, malignant potential, and treatment response.
results_summary: The study found that PVL is not strongly correlated with major risk factors for oral carcinoma (such as tobacco, alcohol, or betel leaf chewing), primarily affects adult/elderly women, and has a high malignant transformation rate with distinct histopathological features.
population_specificity: Adult/elderly women with proliferative verrucous leucoplakia (PVL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the link between areca nut chewing and the development of oral submucous fibrosis (OSF), a premalignant condition.
results_summary: The study found that habitual areca nut chewing leads to OSF, characterized by progressive trismus and collagen deposition in oral mucosa, and is an independent risk factor for oral cancer. Public health education is recommended to mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with habitual areca nut chewing habits, including users of paan masala and gutka.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare pre- and post-rehabilitation changes in mandible movements, chewing cycles, and masticatory efficiency in patients with unilateral muscular disorders (MD) or unilateral disc derangement disorders (DDD) of temporomandibular disorder (TMD) versus healthy controls.
results_summary: Splint therapy significantly improved symptoms (muscle pain, TMJ pain, headache, chewing difficulty, and maximum mouth opening) and chewing efficacy/cycles in both MD and DDD patients, though only MD patients reached comparable levels to healthy controls post-treatment. Lateral excursion and protrusion showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 40 patients with TMD (20 MD, 20 DDD) and 20 healthy controls (48 female, 12 male; mean age 28).

study_goal: To determine if gum chewing accelerates the return of bowel function after complete staging surgery for gynecologic malignancies.
results_summary: Gum chewing significantly reduced time to flatus, defecation, bowel movement, diet tolerance, and hospital stay, while also decreasing mild ileus symptoms compared to controls.
population_specificity: 149 patients undergoing abdominal complete surgical staging for gynecological cancers.
effective_dosage: Sugarless gum chewed three times daily for 30 minutes per session.
study_duration: From the first postoperative morning until the first passage of flatus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential benefits of chewing (specifically sugarless gum) and other agents in minimizing salivary gland side effects induced by radioiodine therapy.
results_summary: The study suggests that lemon candies, lemon juice, and sugarless chewing gum may help minimize salivary gland side effects from radioiodine therapy, though clinical evidence is limited.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing radioiodine therapy for thyroid conditions (e.g., Graves' disease, post-surgical ablation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing gum for the prevention and treatment of oral mucositis in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to make a guideline recommendation for chewing gum due to inadequate or conflicting data. No conclusion on efficacy was possible.
population_specificity: Cancer patients, including those undergoing radiation therapy or high-dose chemotherapy with or without stem cell transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient-reported outcomes, including chewing ability, for maxillary implant-supported overdentures with and without palatal coverage.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in chewing ability between overdentures with and without palatal coverage, but patient satisfaction was higher for esthetics and taste without palatal coverage.
population_specificity: 21 maxillary edentulous patients (6 women, 15 men).
study_duration: 2 months for each overdenture design (total 4 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of cancer stem cells (CSCs) in oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) and their contribution to tumor recurrence, metastasis, and therapy resistance.
results_summary: The study highlights that oral CSCs, characterized by specific gene upregulation and resistance mechanisms, play a pivotal role in tumor relapse and therapy failure, with tobacco chewing identified as a risk factor.
population_specificity: Patients with oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of preventing adolescent tobacco chewing and smoking through a school-based tobacco control program.
results_summary: The study found a baseline prevalence of 2.24% for tobacco chewing habits among students, which declined significantly after the intervention. The program also increased awareness about the ill effects of tobacco, with a statistically significant reduction in future tobacco use desire.
population_specificity: School children (4,144 participants) in 13 randomly selected schools in Kannur district, Kerala.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate a new questionnaire (QoLIP-10) for assessing oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) in implant-prosthesis wearers, focusing on aspects like oral pain and chewing difficulty.
results_summary: The QoLIP-10 was found reliable and valid, with fixed implant hybrid prostheses (HP) wearers reporting better biopsychosocial quality of life, particularly in oral pain and chewing difficulty, compared to other groups.
population_specificity: 150 subjects wearing implant-prostheses or complete dentures, divided into three groups: complete denture wearers (control), implant-retained overdenture wearers, and fixed implant hybrid prostheses wearers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chitosan-containing chewing gum could reduce serum phosphate levels in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
results_summary: Chitosan chewing gum reduced serum phosphate by approximately 0.05-0.065 mmol/l in CKD and ESRD patients, but had no effect on salivary phosphate concentration. The effect was statistically significant in some trials but not in others.
population_specificity: Patients with stage 3-4 CKD and end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
effective_dosage: 20 mg twice daily, 40 mg three times daily, and 20 mg three times daily.
study_duration: 4 weeks for the double-blind trial, 2 weeks for the open-label trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of medicated, sugar-free chewing gum containing antimicrobial agents or herbal extracts on plaque indices and gingival inflammation.
results_summary: Most chewing gums with antimicrobial agents or herbal extracts showed a positive effect on plaque and gingivitis scores, with the strongest evidence for chlorhexidine gum. Other effective ingredients included eucalyptus, acacia, funoran, Pycnogenol, and mastic, though gingivitis data were limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with focus on plaque and gingivitis outcomes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum containing CPP-ACP could enhance mineral precipitation in initial bovine enamel erosion lesions compared to gum without CPP-ACP or no gum.
results_summary: Chewing gum with CPP-ACP significantly improved mineral precipitation (30% microhardness recovery) compared to gum without CPP-ACP (19%) and no gum (10%). The study concluded that CPP-ACP chewing gum was effective in remineralizing eroded enamel.
population_specificity: 12 healthy adult subjects
effective_dosage: Chewed gum 3 times for 30 minutes per phase
study_duration: 1 day per experimental phase (3 phases total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gum chewing could accelerate the recovery of gastrointestinal motility after colorectal surgery.
results_summary: The study found that gum chewing had an uncertain effect on bowel motility, neither significantly accelerating it nor showing no effect. It was among interventions with inconclusive outcomes compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from colorectal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore associations between nutritional deficit and measures of oral health, particularly chewing-related indicators, in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that perception of xerostomia, number of functional units (FU), and GOHAI score were significant parameters explaining variations in nutritional status (MNA). Elderly individuals with fewer FUs, higher xerostomia perception, or lower GOHAI scores were more likely to have or be at risk of malnutrition.
population_specificity: Independent elderly aged 65+ attending primary care clinics in Beirut, Lebanon (121 women, 80 men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in masticatory patterns and electromyographic activity before and after therapy for deep bite malocclusion using a functional appliance.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in EMG activity of masseter and anterior temporalis muscles after therapy, along with increased height and width of chewing cycles in the frontal plane, indicating improved masticatory function.
population_specificity: An 11-year-old boy with deep bite malocclusion (overbite = 5 mm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Mucus III oral moisture meter in diagnosing dry mouth in head and neck tumor patients before and after radiotherapy, comparing it with other objective and subjective measures.
results_summary: The study found that resting and stimulated saliva flow rates significantly decreased at 3 and 12 months after radiotherapy, as indicated by the questionnaire, resting saliva test, and chewing gum test. However, Mucus III results only showed significant worsening of xerostomia at 12 months, indicating a lack of perfect correlation with other measures.
population_specificity: 17 newly diagnosed patients with pharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma or unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma undergoing head and neck radiation therapy.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted before radiotherapy, immediately after, and at 3 and 12 months post-radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postoperative gum chewing improves bowel motility after laparoscopic gynecologic surgery.
results_summary: Gum chewing significantly reduced the time to first flatus and increased bowel sound regularity post-surgery, with fewer opioids needed in the intervention group. No significant difference was found in time to first defecation, and no side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic gynecologic surgery.
effective_dosage: Gum chewing every 2 hours for 15 minutes.
study_duration: Postoperative period until bowel function recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify major risk factors for oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, including chewing, and highlight the role of human papillomavirus infection in non-smoking, non-drinking patients.
results_summary: The study identified chewing as a major risk factor for oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, alongside tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption. It also noted human papillomavirus infection as a significant risk factor in non-smoking, non-drinking patients.
population_specificity: Patients with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, including non-smoking and non-drinking individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze MRI evidence of masticatory muscle alterations after radiotherapy for head and neck cancer.
results_summary: The review found limited evidence of MRI-detectable changes in masticatory muscles post-radiotherapy, with poor-quality studies showing inconsistent results. No specific radiation-induced changes were conclusively identified.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer who underwent radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum containing probiotic bacteria (Lactobacillus reuteri) could influence salivary IgA levels and specific antibody responses against mutans streptococci and the probiotic itself.
results_summary: The test group showed a significant increase in total salivary IgA levels and a decrease in probiotic-reactive and mutans streptococci-specific antibodies post-treatment, while no changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Small sample size (test group n=11, control group n=12).
study_duration: 12 weeks of treatment, with follow-up 4 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in eating habits, including chewing function, in elderly subjects with senile anorexia.
results_summary: The study found that anorexic elderly subjects had reduced global food intake and altered eating patterns, with decreased consumption of certain food groups, while chewing function was assessed as part of the multidimensional evaluation. Nutritional status correlated with diet variety, but chewing-specific outcomes were not detailed.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling and institutionalized elderly subjects (65+ years), including free-living individuals, nursing home residents, and patients in rehabilitation/acute care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically examine the clinical significance of surface EMG of masticatory muscles in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD), focusing on EMG activity during prolonged chewing, mastication, and under various influencing factors.
results_summary: The review included studies on factors like gender, age, tooth status, orofacial morphology, pain, and occlusal relationships, showing that these factors influence EMG activity during chewing and static/dynamic occlusion in TMD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate postoperative hypersensitivity following resin-based composite restoration of occlusal caries and its relationship to materials and techniques used.
results_summary: The study found that 30% of teeth had appreciable hypersensitivity (AH) at baseline, with 10% of teeth developing AH post-treatment. Changes in AH were not associated with materials or techniques, except for a transient effect from antimicrobials at 1 week and a minor association with dentin bonding agent type at 4 weeks.
population_specificity: Patients with early occlusal caries lesions requiring treatment, treated by PEARL Network Practitioner Investigators.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pulverizing lanthanum carbonate (LC) chewable preparations improved clinical efficacy in patients who did not chew them adequately, specifically examining changes in serum phosphorus levels.
results_summary: The study found that pulverizing LC significantly reduced serum phosphorus levels in the non-chewing group (NC group) over 6 weeks, with no significant changes in other patients. Residual LC images on abdominal X-rays also diminished notably.
population_specificity: 41 subjects on maintenance hemodialysis at Minamisenju Hospital (18 in the NC group).
study_duration: 10 weeks (6 weeks of active monitoring post-pulverization)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient-reported outcomes, including chewing ability, between maxillary conventional dentures and maxillary implant-supported dentures.
results_summary: Implant-supported dentures significantly improved chewing ability compared to conventional dentures, along with other aspects of oral health and satisfaction. The study found statistically significant improvements in functional limitation, psychological discomfort, and social disability with implant-supported dentures.
population_specificity: 21 edentulous maxillary patients (6 women, 15 men) with existing denture problems.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (dental intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the oral health benefits of chewing sugar-free gum, including its anti-caries effects, saliva stimulation, and potential enhancements from active agents.
results_summary: Chewing sugar-free gum promotes saliva flow, aiding in sugar clearance, plaque pH neutralization, and remineralization of early caries, with clinical trials showing reduced caries incidence in children. The paper also reviews additional benefits like plaque and stain reduction and discusses the potential of active agents like fluoride and xylitol.
population_specificity: Primarily children, but implications for general oral health are discussed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two sugar-substituted chewing gums (one with CPP-ACP and one without) alongside toothbrushing on clinical, microbiological, and biochemical variables related to caries and gingivitis.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in visible plaque in the hexitol/CPP-ACP gum group, while the pentitol/non-CPP-ACP gum group showed more significant reductions in salivary facultative bacteria, S. mutans, and Lactobacillus spp. However, the clinical relevance of these findings was deemed marginal.
population_specificity: 130 dental students
effective_dosage: Two gum pellets chewed for 20 minutes three times a day after meals (daily polyol consumption: 6.0 g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the marginal adaptation of ceramic and composite CEREC crowns in endodontically treated teeth restored with different post lengths or endocrowns.
results_summary: Loading significantly affected the percentage of "continuous margin" in all groups, with composite CAD-CAM crowns (Paradigm MZ100) showing superior marginal adaptation compared to all-ceramic crowns (IPS Empress CAD). Post length did not significantly influence marginal adaptation.
population_specificity: Forty-eight intact maxillary incisors (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (mechanical loading in a chewing machine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether chewing gum could reduce the duration of postoperative ileus following abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that chewing gum significantly reduced the time to flatus, time to bowel movement, and length of hospital stay, though with significant heterogeneity among studies. Cumulative evidence over six years supported these benefits.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing abdominal surgery (1,374 participants across 17 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate patient-centered outcomes related to function and comfort after placing mini-implants to stabilize complete dentures.
results_summary: The study found that mini-implants significantly improved overall satisfaction, chewing, and speaking comfort, with median VAS scores increasing from 4-5 to 9-10. However, implant failures occurred, particularly with maxillary dentures and short implants (7-10 mm).
population_specificity: 21 subjects aged 50-90 years with poorly stabilized full dentures in the maxilla or mandible.
effective_dosage: 2-4 narrow-body Dentatus Atlas® implants per patient.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quality of life (QOL) of patients undergoing esophagectomy for adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction and squamous cell carcinoma, including assessing symptoms like chewing difficulty.
results_summary: Chewing difficulty was reported by 42% of patients postoperatively, but no significant correlation was found between this symptom and overall quality of life. The study did not focus on chewing as a primary outcome but noted its occurrence as a postoperative symptom.
population_specificity: Postoperative patients who underwent esophagectomy for adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction (10 patients) or squamous cell carcinoma (14 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum, when combined with medication, could improve treatment outcomes for patients with mild to moderate depression compared to medication alone.
results_summary: Patients who received chewing gum alongside medication showed better treatment responses, particularly in alleviating gastrointestinal symptoms like loss of appetite and flatulence, though chewing gum did not directly improve depressed mood.
population_specificity: 30 patients with mild to moderate depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the wear performance of different monolithic dental ceramics (translucent zirconia, shaded zirconia, lithium disilicate) under various surface treatments during simulated chewing.
results_summary: Polished, ground, and repolished zirconia showed no wear, while glazed surfaces were abraded. Lithium disilicate exhibited significantly higher wear than zirconia but less than human enamel. Antagonistic wear was lowest with polished/ground/repolished zirconia and highest with glazed or lithium disilicate surfaces.
population_specificity: Standardized dental ceramic specimens (n = 8 per series).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the clinical and public health implications of tooth agenesis, including its impact on chewing ability, and emphasize the need for early diagnosis and intervention.
results_summary: The study found that tooth agenesis can lead to reduced chewing ability, pronunciation issues, and aesthetic concerns, and stressed the importance of radiographic, clinical, and dental cast examinations for accurate diagnosis. Early diagnosis can help prevent associated dental anomalies and improve patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with tooth agenesis (missing permanent teeth).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to describe a case of involuntary jaw muscle spasms and their impact on chewing and talking.
results_summary: The study found that the patient experienced episodic jaw muscle contractions, which interfered with chewing and talking, and led to frequent tongue biting. The spasms varied in duration and occurred both during waking and sleep.
population_specificity: A 57-year-old man with left-sided facial numbness, shock-like pain, and involuntary jaw movements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sham feeding with chewing gum accelerates gastrointestinal recovery after colorectal resection surgery in patients on a rapid feeding enhanced recovery program.
results_summary: The study found that chewing gum did not hasten the return of gastrointestinal function (time to flatus and bowel motion) but was safe with no complications. The intervention group reported less pain perception on days 2 to 5, with no differences in other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing open and laparoscopic colorectal resection surgery.
effective_dosage: Chewing gum 4 times a day postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between habitual areca nut chewing and the survival prognosis of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) patients.
results_summary: The study found that habitual areca chewing was a significant predictor of poorer ESCC survival, with patients using multiple substances (alcohol, areca nut, and cigarettes) having 1.52 times the risk of early death. The more substances used, the worse the prognosis.
population_specificity: 718 pathology-proven ESCC patients in Taiwan, predominantly male (70.5% stage III or IV), mean age 59.8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if quid chewing is associated with early cytological changes in buccal mucosa by analyzing AgNOR counts and PAP staining in chewers versus non-chewers.
results_summary: Quid chewers showed statistically higher AgNOR counts and a higher percentage of nuclei with ≥5 AgNORs compared to non-chewers, indicating increased proliferative activity. PAP staining revealed 23% of chewers had class II cytology (abnormal), while non-chewers only showed class I (normal).
population_specificity: 30 male quid chewers and non-chewers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of gum chewing (GC) on promoting gastrointestinal function and reducing postoperative ileus after abdominal surgery.
results_summary: GC significantly reduced the time to first flatus and bowel movement, as well as decreased hospitalization length, with no reported complications. Subgroup analyses across different abdominal procedures consistently favored GC.
population_specificity: Postoperative abdominal surgery patients (1,148 cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the prevalence of anorexia and its correlated factors, including chewing problems, in older people living in nursing homes.
results_summary: Chewing problems were identified as a significant factor associated with a nearly 2-fold increased risk of anorexia in older nursing home residents. Anorexia, including cases linked to chewing problems, was associated with a higher risk of all-cause mortality.
population_specificity: Older people living in Italian nursing homes (1904 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) and patient satisfaction after treatment with conventional dental prostheses, focusing on chewing ability, aesthetics, and overall mouth satisfaction.
results_summary: Patients reported improved chewing ability, aesthetics, and satisfaction after receiving conventional prostheses, with metal-based removable partial dentures (M-RPDs) showing the highest therapeutic improvements. However, removable prostheses caused pain/discomfort in some cases, and over 20% of subjects experienced chewing dysfunction.
population_specificity: 153 patients seeking prosthodontic rehabilitation, compared to a reference population of 123 Spanish adults wearing conventional dental prostheses but not seeking treatment.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (prosthetic intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fluoride in controlling dentin hypersensitivity (DHS) and preventing root caries, including its use in chewing gum.
results_summary: Fluoride in chewing gum was questioned due to an unfavorable cost-effectiveness ratio, with no significant positive effects reported for DHS or root caries prevention. Other fluoride preparations showed better efficacy when combined with dentin fluid-obstructing agents or used in higher concentrations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with dentin hypersensitivity or root caries risk inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of repeated oral visual screening on oral cancer incidence and mortality, particularly among users of tobacco and/or alcohol.
results_summary: The study found a 24% reduction in oral cancer mortality among tobacco and/or alcohol users after four rounds of screening, with even greater reductions (38% in incidence and 81% in mortality) for those adhering to all four screening rounds.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 35 and above in Trivandrum district, Kerala, India, particularly users of tobacco and/or alcohol.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (screening intervention, not a dosage-based study).
study_duration: 15-year follow-up with screening rounds at 3-year intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of surgical reconstruction and osteoplasty on improving chewing function in patients with complete cleft lip, alveolar process, and palate.
results_summary: The study found that surgical reconstruction and autogenic spongy bone grafting improved occlusal conditions and chewing function, though bone volume post-healing was lower than the graft volume, necessitating further research to augment healed bone volume.
population_specificity: Patients with complete cleft lip, alveolar process, and palate (unilateral or bilateral).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the relationship between dentition status and subjectively perceived chewing ability in older adults.
results_summary: The review found that chewing ability is closely related to the number and distribution of remaining teeth, though there was disagreement on the exact number of functional tooth units needed for adequate oral function. Treatment should focus on preserving strategic parts of the dental arch critical for chewing.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a sugar-free chewing gum containing zinc acetate and magnolia bark extract in reducing oral volatile sulfur-containing compounds (VSC) compared to a placebo gum.
results_summary: The test chewing gum significantly reduced oral VSC levels by 50.9% after 10 minutes, 27.6% after one hour, and 13.6% after two hours, outperforming the placebo gum at all time points. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 123 healthy adults (67 men, 56 women, mean age 37) with ≥24 teeth, no oral/systemic diseases, and baseline VSC ≥75 ppb.
effective_dosage: 2.23 g gum containing 0.012% zinc acetate and 0.15% magnolia bark extract, chewed for 10 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore predictors for hazardous alcohol-drinking problems, including chewing betel quid, in hospitalized Chinese patients.
results_summary: The study found that chewing betel quid was a predictor for hazardous alcohol-drinking problems, with a prevalence of 19.2% among participants. However, the study did not assess the direct effects or efficacy of chewing betel quid itself.
population_specificity: 484 hospitalized patients at five general teaching hospitals in Taiwan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the time commitment for clinicians and staff involved in recruiting patients for a randomized controlled trial comparing chewing gum to ibuprofen for orthodontic pain relief.
results_summary: The study found that patient recruitment required an average of 19 minutes of clinical time and 110 minutes of non-clinical administrative time per patient, totaling 129 minutes per patient. The abstract does not report efficacy outcomes for chewing gum versus ibuprofen.
population_specificity: Patients with orthodontic pain across seven trial sites.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), including chewing gum, in aiding smoking cessation and whether different forms, dosages, or combinations of NRT influence outcomes.
results_summary: Nicotine gum was effective in increasing smoking cessation rates (RR 1.49, 95% CI 1.40 to 1.60), with higher efficacy observed in highly dependent smokers using 4 mg gum compared to 2 mg. Adverse effects were mild and related to product type, such as mouth irritation from gum.
population_specificity: Smokers attempting to quit.
study_duration: Varied by trial, with follow-up of at least six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define the demographic risk profile and stage at diagnosis among head and neck cancer patients, with a focus on habits like chewing tobacco.
results_summary: The study found that chewing tobacco, especially in combination with smoking and alcohol, was a significant risk factor for head and neck cancer, with buccal mucosa being the most common site for cancer in chewers.
population_specificity: Patients with histologically confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck in Andhra Pradesh, India (2002-2006).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the pattern of symptoms, including chewing problems, experienced by head and neck cancer patients before radiation therapy.
results_summary: The study found that problems with chewing were among the symptoms most often rated as moderate-to-severe in head and neck cancer patients, particularly in those with poorer performance status, higher T classification, or prior treatment.
population_specificity: 270 head and neck cancer patients before beginning radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction between conventional dentures and mini implant anchored overdentures, focusing on chewing ability, retention, aesthetics, and phonation.
results_summary: Mini implant anchored overdentures provided higher satisfaction in chewing ability and retention compared to conventional dentures, with no need for adhesives. Both treatments were satisfactory for aesthetics and phonation, though conventional dentures had more articulation difficulties.
population_specificity: 36 complete edentulous patients (18 per treatment group).

study_goal: To examine the effectiveness of interventions for oropharyngeal dysphagia (including chewing) in children with neurological impairment.
results_summary: The review found insufficient high-quality evidence to conclude the effectiveness of any specific oral-motor therapy for children with neurological impairment, with small sample sizes and methodological limitations in the included studies.
population_specificity: Children with neurological impairment (e.g., cerebral palsy, myotonic dystrophy type 1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare speech performance and levels of oral impairment (including chewing difficulty) between fixed lingual and labial orthodontic appliances.
results_summary: Chewing difficulty was significantly higher in the lingual appliance group after 24 hours of bracket placement. Patients with lingual appliances experienced more untoward effects, particularly during the first month of treatment.
population_specificity: 34 patients with Class I division 1 malocclusion and moderate crowding of upper teeth (mean age ~21 years).
study_duration: Assessments were made before, immediately after, 1 month after, and 3 months after bracket placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the masticatory performance and ability of a simplified method versus a conventional protocol for complete denture fabrication in edentulous patients.
results_summary: Both simplified and conventional denture fabrication methods showed similar masticatory performance and ability, restoring approximately 30% of the function observed in dentate individuals. One questionnaire item favored the simplified method, but overall results were comparable between groups.
population_specificity: Edentulous patients requiring maxillary and mandibular complete dentures (n=39) and a dentate control group (n=17).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (denture fabrication methods compared, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for stroke in Cambodia, with a focus on tobacco chewing or smoking as a primary risk factor.
results_summary: The study identified tobacco chewing or smoking as the main risk factor for stroke in Cambodia. Traditional therapies like moxibustion and cupping were noted as widely practiced for stroke rehabilitation, but their efficacy was not evaluated.
population_specificity: Cambodian population, particularly those at risk for stroke or using traditional therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of gum chewing on gastrointestinal recovery, specifically time to flatus and bowel movement, in postoperative ileus patients.
results_summary: Gum chewing was associated with significantly shortened times to flatus (2.4 vs 2.9 days) and bowel movement (3.2 vs 3.9 days) in an observational cohort study.
population_specificity: Postoperative radical cystectomy patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing gum as a preventative agent for oral mucositis in children.
results_summary: Chewing gum was identified as one of the agents supported by one or two articles for preventing oral mucositis, but the evidence was limited compared to other methods like oral care protocols. The reduction in oral mucositis rates with fair to good evidence ranged from 22% to 52%, though chewing gum's specific contribution was not detailed.
population_specificity: Children at risk of oral mucositis.

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of two hyaluronic acid treatments following arthrocentesis for managing symptoms in patients with TMJ osteoarthritis, focusing on pain during chewing and other functional outcomes.
results_summary: Both low- and medium-molecular weight HA treatments improved pain at chewing, pain at rest, chewing efficiency, functional limitation, and mouth opening, with no significant differences between the two treatments. Perceived effectiveness and tolerability were also similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with TMJ osteoarthritis using Research Diagnostic Criteria for Temporomandibular Disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (protocol involved 5 weekly injections of either low- or medium-molecular weight HA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the causes, clinical features, and treatment options for ectopic third molars in the mandibular condyle, including their impact on chewing.
results_summary: The study found that ectopic third molars in the mandibular condyle often caused symptoms like pain, swelling, and difficulty chewing, with most cases associated with odontogenic cysts. Surgical removal was the primary treatment, with no serious complications reported in most cases.
population_specificity: 15 patients (mostly women, mean age 48.6 years) with ectopic third molars in the mandibular condyle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the germ-killing efficacy of an essential oil mouthrinse (EOM) by measuring blood levels of microorganisms associated with bacteremia induced by chewing and to investigate the prevalence of this event in Brazilians with mild-to-moderate gingivitis.
results_summary: The study found that EOM significantly reduced bacteremia, with mean aerobic counts decreasing by 45.8% and anaerobic counts by 63.3%, while placebo treatment showed an increase in aerobic bacteria (28.4%) and a smaller decrease in anaerobic bacteria (18.5%). The methodology was validated, demonstrating EOM's germ-killing action.
population_specificity: Brazilians with mild-to-moderate gingivitis (34 subjects out of 109 screened).
study_duration: 2 weeks per phase (with a 2-week wash-out period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of CPP-ACP-containing sugar-free chewing gum on salivary calcium and phosphorus concentrations to assess its potential for enamel remineralization.
results_summary: Chewing CPP-ACP-containing gum significantly increased salivary calcium and phosphorus concentrations, suggesting a potential benefit for enamel remineralization over a prolonged period.
population_specificity: 24 selected subjects (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Two pellets of chewing gum, chewed for 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction and masticatory efficiency between single implant-retained mandibular overdentures using stud (Locator) and magnetic (Magfit) attachments.
results_summary: Both attachment types significantly improved patient satisfaction (comfort, speech, chewing ability, retention) and masticatory efficiency, with no significant differences between them except for perceived chewing ability, where Locator performed better.
population_specificity: Patients receiving single implant-retained mandibular overdentures.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (implant attachments, not a supplement).
study_duration: 3 months per attachment type (total 6 months with crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between betel nut/betel quid (BN/BQ) mastication and oral/oropharyngeal cancers, as well as review preventive strategies.
results_summary: BN/BQ mastication is strongly associated with increased susceptibility to oral and oropharyngeal cancers, with tobacco addition marginally increasing risk. Despite widespread use and cancer links, no serious control strategies exist.
population_specificity: Approximately 10% of the world population practicing BN/BQ mastication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of xylitol (administered via chewing gum for mothers and tablets for children) on plaque accumulation, caries activity, and salivary Streptococcus Mutans levels in Saudi mother-child pairs.
results_summary: Xylitol significantly reduced salivary Streptococcus Mutans levels in both mothers and children, and plaque scores decreased significantly in children. However, no significant differences in caries levels were observed between the xylitol and control (fluoride varnish) groups.
population_specificity: 60 Saudi mother-child pairs with high salivary Streptococcus Mutans levels.
effective_dosage: Xylitol chewing gum (mothers) and tablets (children) three times/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticaries effects and safety of polyols, particularly xylitol, in various vehicles like chewing gum, lozenges, and toothpaste.
results_summary: The study found that xylitol is non-cariogenic and has a dose-/frequency-dependent antimicrobial effect on dental plaque/mutans streptococci, with polyol use being very safe. However, caries data interpretation remains controversial due to variability in study designs and outcomes.
population_specificity: At-risk populations for dental caries (specific age groups not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the wear resistance of human enamel and feldspathic porcelain against different ceramic materials during simulated chewing.
results_summary: The study found that feldspathic porcelain (Vita-Omega 900) caused the most enamel wear, followed by lithium disilicate (IPS e.max Press), while zirconia ceramics (Prettau, Lava, Rainbow) caused the least wear. Enamel wear was significantly greater than feldspathic porcelain wear, regardless of ceramic surface roughness.
population_specificity: Human teeth and ceramic materials (not a living population).
